payload.posterTitle: Africa: Where Earth Blooms, Burns, and Breathes

biomes.name: Cape Floristic Region
biomes.description: At Africa’s southern tip, the Cape Floristic Region bursts with fynbos plants like proteas and heaths. Ocean winds and regular fires help this tiny area hold an incredible number of unique species.

biomes.name: Madagascar Spiny Forests
biomes.description: Madagascar’s spiny forests are dry, thorny thickets filled with succulents and baobabs. Many plants and animals here live nowhere else, shaped by long droughts and harsh sun.

biomes.name: Ethiopian Highlands
biomes.description: Ethiopia’s highlands rise into cool grasslands and cliffs. Gelada monkeys graze like sheep, and rare Ethiopian wolves hunt on open slopes among giant lobelias and rocky peaks.

biomes.name: Danakil Depression
biomes.description: The Danakil Depression is one of Earth’s hottest places. It glows with sulfur colors, salt flats, and steaming vents—an extreme landscape built by volcanoes and minerals.

biomes.name: Sudd Wetlands
biomes.description: South Sudan’s Sudd is a vast Nile swamp that swells with seasonal floods. Papyrus reeds, floating plants, and winding channels create a wetland maze packed with birds and fish.

biomes.name: Lake Tanganyika
biomes.description: Lake Tanganyika is one of the world’s oldest and deepest lakes. Its clear waters hold hundreds of unique fish species, while steep shores and distant mountains frame the long, narrow lake.

biomes.name: Virunga Mountains
biomes.description: The Virunga Mountains are misty volcanoes draped in rainforest. Their slopes shelter mountain gorillas, and nearby craters and lava fields show how fire and life share the same ground.
